sections.PURPOSE: of this LFX block is to certify crews, squads, and platoons for UCRF and LFX progression in preparation for the EDRE to Poland. This is critical because it enables future training as well as ensures that our platoons are lethal combat formations.
sections.KEY TASKS:
Certify our leaders and empower them to train squads, crews, and individuals.
Certify all Stryker crews in the Squadron.
Certify Lightning Troop’s platoons and Iron Troop’s squads.
As feasible, qualify all individual weapon systems prior to collective LFXs.
Conduct field maintenance throughout the operation IOT come out of training with the highest readiness possible.
Maximize concurrent training.
Endstate: All Squadron crews, Iron Squads, and Lightning Platoons are qualified.
Concurrent training is maximized and Troop level

sections.SUSTAINMENT:
CL I (R): Ration cycle is A-M-A. Each Troop supply will pick up mermites (AMA) from DFAC. Troop supply is responsible for plasticware/cups CL III (P): Fueler will rotate to each range between dry period (0500-0800). Emergency resupply at night down time (1800-2100). Troops will have all fuel cans on hand topped off for emergency resupply. CL V: Ammunition will be dropped off upon occupation by Lightning Troop. Lightning Troop is responsible for coordinating drop off with Fury Troop. If drop off the day prior to beginning training is not feasible, Fury will drop off 0500-0600.
Maintenance: Fury will maintain one contact truck at VAAF (14-15MAR) each gunnery range (15-20MAR) and at Lightning’s PLT LFX (21-22MAR.) A wrecker will be on standby at Rose Barracks 14-16MAR and 21-23MAR. From 17-20MAR, the wrecker will be located at Range 112.
Maintenance priorities can be found on the SQDN Synchmat.

draw.mission_task_and_description: 3D Squadron 2D Cavalry Regiment Stryker Crew/Platform Qualification

values: Plan SDZs, battle positions, and maneuver boxes with Range Control to ensure the conduct of the range is safe and mitigates the risk of fratricide.
All crews briefed on the approved range SDZ, maneuver boxes, and battle positions.
Brief duties and expectations for safety and control to all range safeties prior to execution.
Prior to each iteration, the RSO and range safeties will confirm all personnel are clear from down range. Day and night safety briefs will occur.
Safeties will move with each vehicle and ensure the crew is firing within the limits of the range.

Day and Night safety briefs will be briefed by OIC/RSO Range certified OIC/RSO Medic aid bag inventory Senior medic makes recommendation to OIC/RSO on AXP/CCP location Maintain communication to the lowest levels
Prior to execution, crews will receive a brief on the approved SDZ of each maneuver box and battle position.
Range orientation brief during daily range safety brief by RSO.
Range fans identified by each crew prior to execution.
Range fans clearly marked and visible.
Weapon systems properly cleared before leaving the firing line.
Range orientation brief from the OIC/RSO prior to training. Crew identify range fans before each iteration.
RSO/ OIC Range Safeties VCEs Vehicle Crew

subtasks.hazard: Negligent Discharge or Weapon Malfunction Causing Bodily Harm

values: required PPE while on the range.
Lane safeties and the OIC / RSO will ensure weapon systems are properly oriented downrange and operating in a safe manner at all times.
Weapons will be visual cleared by RSO following completion of the lane.
All weapons will be inspected by SL/ PSG prior to moving to any range.
Weapons will be pointed downrange at all times away from personnel when loaded.
Ensure a Medic and a dedicated evacuation vehicle (FLA) is available at all times.
PMI Conduct safety brief prior to each phase TC and VC Physically inspect to ensure manual safe is engaged Conduct clearing procedure in accordance with TM
RSO/ OIC Range Safeties Vehicle Crew
posted at all entry points to the range and at high traffic areas.

subtask.name: MOVEMENT TO, FROM, AND ON TRAINING SITE

values: vehicle PMCS prior to movement, all Soldier's will adhere to posted speed limit signs, drive
Ground guides will be used when maneuvering all vehicles onto the range.
Sleeping areas will be marked with Chem lights and engineer tape. Soldiers will not sleep next to any vehicle.
Ground guides will be used entering and exiting motor pools.
Use of proper hand and arm signals when maneuvering all vehicles.
Conduct safety brief at each phase, addressing: speed, route, and vehicle safety

subtask.name: MOVEMENT TO, FROM, AND ON TRAINING SITE

values: Brief crews on procedures during limited visibility conditions.
Soldiers will use NODs, DVEs, and RWS FLIR during limited visibility and night time operations.
White light will be use when conducting admin moves.
Ground guides will be used during times of degraded visibility.
PCCs and PCIs Brief limited visibility conditions during safety brief.

subtasks.hazard: Combustions / Fire at the ammo point

values: least two 10 pound fire extinguishers on hand.
No smoking withing 50m of ammo point
Ammo will be stored in accordance with QUASAS Range OPS, and 2CR policy.
Ammo point inspected by RSO and OIC
Use of snow chains when snow and ice are on the ground.
Reduce vehicle speed based on road condition
Use of ground guides and chem lights during poor visibility due to weather.
If lightning is in the immediate area all personnel will move to the nearest grounded hard stand structure or spread out in low ground away from all equipment.
Ensure Soldiers know how toi nstall snow chains properly. Brief inclement weather condition and safety measures during safety brief
Brief all Soldiers on procedure when finding a UXO.
Clear the area surrounding the UXO.
Mark UXO, call EOD and Range Operations.
OIC will monitor temperature and humidity of ground surface.
Verify fire danger posted by Range Operation daily.
Identify fire team and have appropriate FFE on-hand and ready.
OIC will place range in "DRY" status and notify Range Operation.
Soldiers to use. Leaders and medics will enforce hydration and constantly monitor for symptoms of heat exhaustion.
Cold weather clothing included on the Range packing list.

draw.overall_supervision_plan: The OIC, RSO, and range leadership will conduct a range safety brief prior to all live fire training. The OIC and RSO are overall responsible for safety. However, team leaders, squad leaders, and VCEs have the responsibility to be actively engaged in range activities and Soldier actions so as to mitigate risk at the lowest level possible and ensure overall safety for the training event.
